name: Kepler-9
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-9 Exoplanetary System


Overview

Kepler-9 is a star with 1.02 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.96 times its radius. It is located 2002.60 light years away from the solar system and is estimated to be 2 billion years old, as compared to the Sun which is roughly 4.6 billion years old.

Kepler-9 is known to have 3 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the Kepler-9 system


Kepler-9 b

Kepler-9 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.14 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of Kepler-9 b is 43.4229 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-9 b is 8.29 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, Kepler-9 b is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.


Kepler-9 c

Kepler-9 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.23 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of Kepler-9 c is 29.91744 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-9 c is 8.08 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, Kepler-9 c is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.


Kepler-9 d

Kepler-9 d was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.03 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The radius of Kepler-9 d is 1.64 that of Earth.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-9, which contains 3 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
